newsitem.title: UK: Pakistan plans regular presence in Eurobond market.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan plans regular presence in Eurobond market.

text.p: Pakistan is gearing up to raise money in the international bond market regularly and will offer investors a dollar Eurobond this month, a Pakistan ministry of finance official said on Thursday.
The upcoming deal will be the first time investors are able to gain exposure to Pakistan following the change of the Benazir Bhutto government.
"We would like to access the international capital markets two to three times a year," Javed Ahmed Noel said, adding Pakistan would also like to extend the maturity of its debt.
The country is also considering the launch of a medium term note programme, he said.

Speaking in London ahead of the launch of Pakistan's three-year floating rate note, he said Pakistan was also planning bonds in other currencies -- including a Samurai of around 10 billion yen with a three- to five-year maturity and the possibility of a sterling bond.
Noel said the proceeds of the dollar-denominated bond would be used for oil imports. "Our energy discoveries are improving but we still need to import a lot of oil."
ANZ Investment Bank was mandated to lead the well-flagged transaction, expected to pay between 375 and 425 basis points over LIBOR. Launch is expected May 20.
"I can't see us going over 400, and if the strength of the order book is good, we could do it at 350," ANZ head of new issues and origination Barry Field said.
The deal is also expected to be increased from its mooted $100 million, Field said. He said a fixed rate bond would have had difficulty due to the rising interest rate scenario in the U.S.
"The timing of this deal is excellent and we think this is a good story," Field said.
Pakistan is rated B plus by Standard & Poor's and B2 by Moody's Investors Services.
"Investors are cautious, but we think Pakistan is a good story and the potential for a rating improvement is there," Field said.
He said key demand was expected to come from the Middle East, European and Asian banks.
